{"uri": "8219100302", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:53:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:53:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:52:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/07/10/biden-ally-pelosi-raises-doubts-about-race-clooney-calls-for-exit/", "title": "Biden ally Pelosi raises doubts about race, Clooney calls for exit", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on Wednesday while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nIn an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he remains in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of doubts from fellow Democrats.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular\".\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump. It also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later on Wednesday, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nCLOONEY WITHDRAWS SUPPORT\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nBiden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, including his forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.", "source": {"uri": "cyprus-mail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cyprus Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular\".\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump. It also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later today, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nCLOONEY WITHDRAWS SUPPORT\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, today, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nBiden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, including his forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. He will hold meetings today with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, {"uri": "8219027695", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:00:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:00:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:00:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.jpost.com/us-elections/article-809793", "title": "Democrat Pelosi raises doubts about race, Clooney withdraws support", "body": "In an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nUS President Joe Biden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on Wednesday while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nIn an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he remains in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of doubts from fellow Democrats.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular.\"\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump. It also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later on Wednesday, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nClooney withdraws support\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nBiden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, including his forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.", "source": {"uri": "jpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Jerusalem Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8219044534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:11:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:11:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:11:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/biden-ally-nancy-pelosi-raises-doubts-about-race-george-clooney-calls-for-exit/article_37ac557c-9291-537f-bcf0-db59376e2a8c.html", "title": "Biden ally Nancy Pelosi raises doubts about race, George Clooney calls for exit", "body": "By Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -U.S. President Joe Biden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on Wednesday while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nIn an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he remains in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of doubts from fellow Democrats.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular\".\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump. It also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later on Wednesday, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nCLOONEY WITHDRAWS SUPPORT\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nBiden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, including his forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\n(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason; additional reporting by Susan Heavey; Editing by Heather Timmons and Howard Goller)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "label": {"eng": "Nancy Pelosi"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Joe Biden"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417275455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:23:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:23:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T09:10:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://arab.news/5zrpd", "title": "Biden meets union leaders as Democrats' calls to exit race continue", "body": "Democrats in the US Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside\n\nWASHINGTON: US President Joe Biden returns to the campaign trail on Wednesday, rallying the key constituency of labor leaders, as some fellow Democrats continue to persuade him not to run again.\n\nFor the past 13 days, the 81-year-old Biden has been working to stem defections from Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after his halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nBiden will join the AFL-CIO's executive council meeting in Washington on Wednesday to take questions from leaders of major US labor unions and discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump this November,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania and Nevada, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in the US Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nOn Tuesday, Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race.\n\nMany more Democrats have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House of Representatives members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nLabor leaders expected at Wednesday's meeting include the national presidents of 60 unions, representing 12.5 million Americans, Biden aides said.\n\nAlso this week, Biden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, with a forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state. The dinner would not normally draw much attention, but concerns over whether Biden can handle the demands of the presidency for another four years have put every Biden event in the spotlight.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc. in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit ends, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\nWhite House spokesperson Karine Jean-Pierre faced another salvo of questions from reporters about Biden's health on Tuesday. In a statement, the White House physician said Biden was not being treated for any neurological condition and had received a clean bill of health at his most recent physical examination in February.", {"uri": "8219299149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:44:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:44:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:43:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/clooney-were-not-going-win-president", "title": "Clooney: 'We're not going to win with this president", "body": "You are not permitted to download, save or email this image. Visit image gallery to purchase the image.\n\nUnited States President Joe Biden is facing fresh doubts about his re-election chances from two heavyweights who may influence other Democratic lawmakers and financial donors: Nancy Pelosi and George Clooney.\n\nBiden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on MSNBC while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nHollywood star Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support with a damning opinion piece in the New York Times saying that Biden was not the same man he was in 2020.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he is staying in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of calls from fellow Democrats to exit the race.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the November 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance in Atlanta.\n\nThe President has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump, a former president. Biden said he had a bad night at the debate and vowed to stay in the race.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular.\"\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nBiden's campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon and senior advisers Mike Donilon and Steve Ricchetti will brief Senate Democrats at a lunch on Thursday, Biden's campaign said.\n\nAsked to comment on Pelosi's remarks and Clooney's article, Biden's campaign pointed to a letter he sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump.\n\nAsked at the NATO summit whether he still had Pelosi's support, Biden responded by raising a triumphant fist.\n\nHowever, other Democrats' echoed Pelosi on Wednesday, suggesting Biden's efforts to quell dissent within his party had not succeeded. Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal said he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nIn Dallas, Vice President Kamala Harris, the party frontrunner to replace Biden if he were to step aside as the Democratic candidate, spoke to a group of some 19,000 people at an event of the historically Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority.\n\nThe election is the most \"existential\" and consequential of their lifetimes, Harris said to a crowd that chanted, \"Four More Years!\"\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fundraiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labour leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO (America's Unions) executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nBiden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labour.\"\n\nLabour {"uri": "8218472618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:18:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:18:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T10:13:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.brecorder.com/news/40312232", "title": "Joe Biden meets union leaders as Democrats' calls to exit race continue", "body": "WASHINGTON: US President Joe Biden returns to the campaign trail on Wednesday, rallying the key constituency of labor leaders, as some fellow Democrats continue to persuade him not to run again.\n\nFor the past 13 days, the 81-year-old Biden has been working to stem defections from Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after his halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nBiden will join the AFL-CIO's executive council meeting in Washington on Wednesday to take questions from leaders of major US labor unions and discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump this November,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nNATO leaders seek to bolster Ukraine as gloom grows\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania and Nevada, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in the US Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity.\n\nBiden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nOn Tuesday, Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race.\n\nMany more Democrats have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House of Representatives members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside. Biden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters.\n\nHis campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform.\n\nLast September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nLabor leaders expected at Wednesday's meeting include the national presidents of 60 unions, representing 12.5 million Americans, Biden aides said.\n\nAlso this week, Biden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, with a forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\nOn Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nThe dinner would not normally draw much attention, but concerns over whether Biden can handle the demands of the presidency for another four years have put every Biden event in the spotlight.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit ends, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\nJoe Biden back on campaign trail as pressure mounts\n\nWhite House spokesperson Karine Jean-Pierre faced another salvo of questions from reporters about Biden's health on Tuesday.\n\nIn a statement, the White House physician said Biden was not being treated for any neurological condition and had received a clean bill of health at his most recent physical examination in February.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8219310900", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "20:00:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T20:00:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:56:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/biden-allies-pelosi-clooney-raise-fresh-doubts-about-his-reelection-chance/2169348/", "title": "Biden allies Pelosi, Clooney raise fresh doubts about his reelection chance", "body": "Hollywood star Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support with a damning opinion piece in the New York Times saying that Biden was not the same man he was in 2020.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he is staying in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of calls from fellow Democrats to exit the race.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump. He said he had a bad night at the debate and vowed to stay in the race.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular.\"\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nBiden's campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon and senior advisers Mike Donilon and Steve Ricchetti will brief Senate Democrats at a lunch on Thursday, Biden's campaign said.\n\nAsked to comment on Pelosi's remarks and Clooney's article, Biden's campaign pointed to a letter he sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pelosi said that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden, the campaign noted. On Wednesday, she told ABC News she thought Biden could win in November.\n\nAsked at the NATO summit whether he still had Pelosi's support, Biden responded by raising a triumphant fist.\n\nHowever, other Democrats' echoed Pelosi on Wednesday, suggesting Biden's efforts to quell dissent within his party had not succeeded. Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal said he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nIn Dallas, Vice President Kamala Harris, the party frontrunner to replace Biden if he were to step aside as the Democratic candidate, spoke to a group of some 19,000 people at an event of the historically Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority.\n\nThe election is the most \"existential\" and consequential of their lifetimes, Harris said to a crowd that chanted, \"Four More Years!\"\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nBiden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\n(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason; additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Jarrett Renshaw; Editing by Heather Timmons and Howard Goller)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@theprint.in", "name": "Reuters", {"uri": "8219068498", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:30:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:30:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T16:28:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13620665/Biden-ally-Nancy-Pelosi-raises-doubts-race-George-Clooney-calls-exit.html", "title": "Biden ally Nancy Pelosi raises doubts about race, George Clooney...", "body": "'Time is running short,' former House speaker says\n\n*\n\nFundraiser Clooney withdraws support, says Biden cannot win\n\n(Adds reaction to Pelosi from campaign official, George Clooney, meeting with senior labor leaders, paragraphs 1-13)\n\nBy Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason\n\nWASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters) - U.S. President Joe Biden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on Wednesday while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nIn an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he remains in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of doubts from fellow Democrats.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular\".\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump. It also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later on Wednesday, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nCLOONEY WITHDRAWS SUPPORT\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It\u00b4s devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn\u00b4t even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won\u00b4t win the House, and we\u00b4re going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nBiden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, including his forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\n(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason; additional reporting by Susan Heavey; Editing by Heather Timmons and {"uri": "2024-07-417424735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:08:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/unions-democrat-voter/2024/07/10/id/1171889/", "title": "Biden Meets Union Leaders as Dems' Calls to Exit Race Continue", "body": "President Joe Biden returns to the campaign trail Wednesday, rallying the key constituency of labor leaders, as some fellow Democrats continue to persuade him not to run again.\n\nFor the past 13 days, the 81-year-old Biden has been working to stem defections from Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after his halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nBiden will join the AFL-CIO's executive council meeting in Washington on Wednesday to take questions from leaders of major U.S. labor unions and discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump this November,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's victory over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania and Nevada, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in the U.S. Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nRep. Mikie Sherrill, D-N.J., became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race.\n\nMany more Democrats have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House of Representatives members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nLabor leaders expected at Wednesday's meeting include the national presidents of 60 unions, representing 12.5 million Americans, Biden aides said.\n\nAlso this week, Biden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, with a forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state. The dinner would not normally draw much attention, but concerns over whether Biden can handle the demands of the presidency for another four years have put every Biden event in the spotlight.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit ends, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\nWhite House spokesperson Karine Jean-Pierre faced another salvo of questions from reporters about Biden's health Tuesday. In a statement, the White House physician said Biden was not being treated for any neurological condition and had received a clean bill of health at his most recent physical examination in February.", {"uri": "8219281608", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:27:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:27:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:26:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/politics/election/pelosi-raises-doubts-clooney-urges-biden-to-exit-race-c-15312998", "title": "Pelosi raises doubts, Clooney urges Biden to exit race", "body": "US President Joe Biden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has said while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nIn an opinion piece published on Wednesday in the New York Times, Hollywood star George Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he remains in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of doubts from fellow Democrats.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the November 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington DC this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular\".\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run.\n\n\"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said.\n\n\"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nAsked to respond, Biden's campaign referred to a letter Biden sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump.\n\nIt also noted Pelosi's remark on Tuesday that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden.\n\nDemocratic Senator Richard Blumenthal echoed Pelosi's message later on Wednesday, saying he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nOften described as an \"ATM for Democrats,\" Hollywood has traditionally been a significant source of donations for the party.\n\nClooney's event, hosted with actor Julia Roberts, raised more than $US30 million ($A44 million) in what the Biden campaign said was the largest Democratic fundraiser in history.\n\nAfter Biden's debate performance, several Hollywood donors called on the president to end his campaign.\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labour leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington DC to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nAt the meeting, Biden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said.\n\n\"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labour.\"\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity.\n\nBiden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nSome have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly.\n\nNo members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside although {"uri": "8215959345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-08", "time": "22:34:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-08T22:34:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-08T22:28:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13613651/jill-president-joe-biden-2024-race-drop-out.html", "title": "Jill Biden suggests she is NOT behind Joe's decision to stay in race", "body": "First lady Jill Biden on Monday suggested she is not behind President Joe Biden's determination to stay in the 2024 presidential race as the couple goes on the offensive to keep the Democratic party in line.\n\nShe also lectured the press corps traveling with her on asking her questions about the president's standing with the party.\n\n'Why are you screaming at me? You know me. Don't scream at me. Just talk,' the first lady said with a smile after she made an unscheduled stop at a coffee shop in Tampa, Fla.\n\nBut she still didn't answer any questions about the president's health or Democrats' concerns about his ability to beat Donald Trump.\n\nJill Biden spent Monday on a three-state tour to tout Biden's committment to veterans\n\nThe first lady is on a three-state tour to launch Veterans and Military Families for Biden. In her remarks, she emphasized the administration's committment to veterans and reassured the crowd President Biden is staying in the 2024 contest.\n\n'For all the talk out there about this race, Joe has made it clear that he's all in,' she said.\n\nAnd, while she didn't directly address the rumors that she was behind his decision, she did indirectly hint to it.\n\n'That's the decision he's made and just as he has always supported my career, I am all in too. I know you are too or you wouldn't be here today. And with four more years Joe will continue to fight for you,' she said.\n\nThe crowds reacted with cheers, yelling variations of 'yes' and 'four more years.'\n\nBiden was greeted with friendly crowds at all three venues.\n\nVoters at them told DailyMail.com that while they acknowledged the president's bad night at the debate, they were still backing him over Donald Trump.\n\nThe venues were filled with cheering supporters, Biden-Harris signs and out pourings of affection for the first lady as she campaigned in the three battleground states.\n\nBut there were protesters too - at all three stops. In North Carolina and Georgia, Trump supporters waved flags as the Jill Biden's motorcade drove by. In Florida, there were protesters of the president's policy in Gaza, with one sign reading 'Genocide Jill' - a play on the 'Genocide Joe' signs that have followed the president.\n\nJill Biden's message matched Joe Biden's as the president spent Monday on the offensive, sending a letter to Congressional Democrats declaring he was staying in the race. He also held a call with donors, telling them he was 'done talking about the debate.'\n\n'We need to move forward. Look, we have roughly 40 days til the convention, 120 days til the election. We can't waste any more time being distracted,' Biden said, according to a recording obtained by Politico.\n\nJill Biden shakes hands at a campaign event in Tampa, Fla., on Monday\n\nJill Biden led the charge on moving forward. She is one of the president's closest advisers and seen as one of the few people who could convince him to step down as the Democratic nominee.\n\nBut she made it clear she was 'all in,' spending the day attacking Trump for his record on veterans and arguing the former president should not be in power.\n\nShe told the military-heavy crowds that she and Joe Biden know what it's like to be in the armed services. Their late son Beau served in Afghanistan in the Delaware National Guard.\n\n'This is personal for us. We know what it's like to connect with a lagging phone call from across the world, to smile through another holiday at the table. Let me ask you this: Does Donald Trump - does Donald Trump know what it's like?,' she said.\n\nShe repeated the story of how Donald Trump called soldiers 'losers' and 'suckers' - a story which Trump denies.\n\n'He's evil,' she said in Georgia of the former president.\n\n'He didn't want to be seen with injured veterans because it didn't look good for him. It's disgraceful. But it's not surprising,' she said.\n\nShe also warned what would happen if Trump returned to the White House.\n\n'Donald Trump wakes up every morning thinking of one person and one person only: himself,' she said.\n\nAnd she specifically mentioned the recent Supreme Court ruling that presidents have immunity while they are in office.\n\n'We know what Donald Trump is like as commander-in-chief. He dismissed the military community diminished. America's leader ship around the world. It could be worse this time. He said he wants to be a dictator from day one,' she said.\n\nShe noted the recent Supreme Court decision that ruled presidents have immunity from official actions while in office.\n\n'Our democracy cannot stand a Trump presidency with virtually no limits,' she warned.\n\nThe Biden family has circled the wagons around the president.\n\nJill Biden and Hunter Biden are now acting as the president's gatekeepers.\n\nThe president's sister, Valerie Biden Owens, is also standing by him. Owens ran Joe Biden's first Senate campaign and has been involved in every one of his campaigns since. She is his top political adviser.\n\nJill, Hunter and Valerie are the three most important people in any decision Joe Biden makes about his future.\n\nHe listens to them the most. They would need to give their blessing from him to exit the presidential race.\n\nThey show no signs of doing so.\n\nThe Biden clan gathered at Camp David last weekend for a pre-planned photo shoot with famed photographer Annie Leibovitz. But the main topic of conversation was Biden's disastrous debate performance against Trump.\n\nBoth Jill Biden and President Biden have criticized Donald Trump for his comments on veterans, particularly on a report that he called them 'suckers' and 'losers.' Trump has denied those comments\n\nAll the family urged Bien to stay in the race.\n\nJill Biden, in particular, points to all the family has had to endure during Joe Biden's time in the White House.\n\nShe noted the prosecutor of Hunter Biden, NBC News reported, pointing out he could go to prison. The family - and even some Republicans - saw Hunter's prosecution on a 2018 gun purchase as too much over reach.\n\nJill Biden argued now was the time to fight.\n\nThere is another reason the Bidens are digging in their heels. The family, particularly Jill Biden, remembers how Joe Biden was forced out of the 1988 presidential race after a plagiarism scandal.\n\n'In 1987, she saw him be forced out by the press, pundits and polls, and it was really a scarring experience for both of them,' Michael LaRosa, the first lady's former press secretary, told the New York Times.\n\nHe said had discussed the 1988 episode multiple times with the first lady when he worked for her.\n\n'I think they learned from that experience and they weren't going to have their hands forced like they were in 1987.'", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-417265596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "10:18:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T10:18:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T05:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-meets-union-leaders-democrats-calls-exit-race-continue-2024-07-10/", "title": "Biden meets union leaders as Democrats' calls to exit race continue", "body": "WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters) - U.S. President Joe Biden returns to the campaign trail on Wednesday, rallying the key constituency of labor leaders, as some fellow Democrats continue to persuade him not to run again.\n\nFor the past 13 days, the 81-year-old Biden has been working to stem defections from Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after his halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nBiden will join the AFL-CIO's executive council meeting in Washington on Wednesday to take questions from leaders of major U.S. labor unions and discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump this November,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Pennsylvania and Nevada, in 2020.\n\nDemocrats in the U.S. Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity. Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nOn Tuesday, Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race.\n\nMany more Democrats have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House of Representatives members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labor leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nLabor leaders expected at Wednesday's meeting include the national presidents of 60 unions, representing 12.5 million Americans, Biden aides said.\n\nAlso this week, Biden has used the NATO summit as a global stage, with a forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin. On Wednesday, he will hold meetings with NATO leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state. The dinner would not normally draw much attention, but concerns over whether Biden can handle the demands of the presidency for another four years have put every Biden event in the spotlight.\n\nVice President Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the NATO summit ends, Biden will hit the road again, traveling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\nWhite House spokesperson Karine Jean-Pierre faced another salvo of questions from reporters about Biden's health on Tuesday. In a statement, the White House physician said Biden was not being treated for any neurological condition and had received a clean bill of health at his most recent physical examination in February.\n\nReporting by Trevor Hunnicutt; Editing by Heather Timmons and Miral Fahmy", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Reuters"}, "authors": [{"uri": Biden has said he is fit to serve but understands the questions.\n\nOn Tuesday, Representative Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey became the seventh House Democrat to call on Biden publicly to drop out of the race.\n\nMany more Democrats have expressed concern that Biden continuing at the top of the ticket could cost the party the White House and both houses of Congress in November.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House of Representatives members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden's first 2020 campaign rally, in 2019, was at a Pittsburgh union hall, and the president has made his thick-as-thieves alignment with Big Labour leaders a major pillar of his populist economic platform. Last September, he became the first sitting president to join a union strike when he met United Auto Workers asking for raises.\n\nLabour leaders expected at Wednesday's meeting include the national presidents of 60 unions, representing 12.5-million Americans, Biden aides said.\n\nAlso this week, Biden has used the Nato summit as a global stage, with a forceful speech denouncing Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\nOn Wednesday, he will hold meetings with Nato leaders and then host a dinner for heads of state. The dinner would not normally draw much attention, but concerns over whether Biden can handle the demands of the presidency for another four years have put every Biden event in the spotlight.\n\nVice-president Kamala Harris, who is the party's top alternative should Biden drop his candidacy, will speak to the Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc in Dallas after a Las Vegas campaign stop on Tuesday.\n\nAfter the Nato summit ends, Biden will hit the road again, travelling to two of the competitive states, Michigan and Nevada, that he must sway to defeat Trump.\n\nWhite {"uri": "8219295405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:40:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:40:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:40:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/biden-allies-pelosi-clooney-raise-fresh-doubts-about-his-reelection-chance/article_37ac557c-9291-537f-bcf0-db59376e2a8c.html", "title": "Biden allies Pelosi, Clooney raise fresh doubts about his reelection chance", "body": "By Trevor Hunnicutt, Jeff Mason and Jarrett Renshaw\n\nWASHINGTON/DALLAS (Reuters) -U.S. President Joe Biden faced fresh doubts on Wednesday about his re-election chances from two heavyweights who may influence other Democratic lawmakers and financial donors: Nancy Pelosi and George Clooney.\n\nBiden must decide quickly whether to stay in the 2024 White House race, former House Speaker Pelosi, a longtime Biden ally, said on MSNBC while declining to say definitively that she wanted him to run.\n\nHollywood star Clooney, a Democrat who co-hosted a fundraiser for Biden last month, withdrew his support with a damning opinion piece in the New York Times saying that Biden was not the same man he was in 2020.\n\nPelosi's remarks, which ignored Biden's repeated insistence that he is staying in the race, suggested he could face a fresh wave of calls from fellow Democrats to exit the race.\n\nFor nearly two weeks the 81-year-old Biden has sought to stem defections by Democratic lawmakers, donors and other allies worried he might lose the Nov. 5 vote to Republican Donald Trump, 78, after Biden's halting June 27 debate performance.\n\nThe president has said again and again that he will be the Democratic candidate and that he believes he can beat Trump. He said he had a bad night at the debate and vowed to stay in the race.\n\nPelosi said on MSNBC she was encouraging her colleagues on Capitol Hill with concerns about Biden to refrain from airing them while he hosts NATO leaders in Washington this week.\n\n\"I've said to everyone: let's just hold off. Whatever you're thinking, either tell somebody privately, but you don't have to put that out on the table until we see how we go this week,\" she said, describing Biden's strong remarks at the NATO summit on Tuesday as \"spectacular.\"\n\nShe declined to say definitively that she wanted Biden to run. \"I want him to do whatever he decides to do,\" she said. \"We're all encouraging him to make that decision because time is running short.\"\n\nBiden's campaign chair Jen O'Malley Dillon and senior advisers Mike Donilon and Steve Ricchetti will brief Senate Democrats at a lunch on Thursday, Biden's campaign said.\n\nAsked to comment on Pelosi's remarks and Clooney's article, Biden's campaign pointed to a letter he sent Democrats in Congress that said he was \"firmly committed\" to staying in the race and beating Trump.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pelosi said that she had \"always been committed\" to Biden, the campaign noted. On Wednesday, she told ABC News she thought Biden could win in November.\n\nAsked at the NATO summit whether he still had Pelosi's support, Biden responded by raising a triumphant fist.\n\nHowever, other Democrats' echoed Pelosi on Wednesday, suggesting Biden's efforts to quell dissent within his party had not succeeded. Democratic Senator Richard Blumenthal said he was \"deeply concerned\" about Biden's ability to win the race.\n\nIn Dallas, Vice President Kamala Harris, the party frontrunner to replace Biden if he were to step aside as the Democratic candidate, spoke to a group of some 19,000 people at an event of the historically Black Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority.\n\nThe election is the most \"existential\" and consequential of their lifetimes, Harris said to a crowd that chanted, \"Four More Years!\"\n\nCLOONEY WITHDRAWS SUPPORT\n\nIn his opinion piece, Clooney wrote: \"It's devastating to say it, but the Joe Biden I was with three weeks ago at the fund-raiser was not the Joe 'big F-ing deal' Biden of 2010. He wasn't even the Joe Biden of 2020. He was the same man we all witnessed at the debate,\" Clooney wrote.\n\n\"We are not going to win in November with this president. On top of that, we won't win the House, and we're going to lose the Senate.\"\n\nDemocrats in Congress remain deeply divided over whether to fall in line behind Biden or to urge him to step aside because of persistent questions about his health and acuity.\n\nBut public defections remain a small segment of the 213 Democratic-aligned House members, and the party's leadership continues to back Biden publicly. No members of the Senate have publicly said Biden should stand aside, though Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado said on Tuesday he did not believe Biden could beat Trump.\n\nBiden, eager to change the story, has surrounded himself with communities of his staunchest supporters, including Black Democratic lawmakers and voters. His campaign has framed sticking with Biden as a return of the loyalty he has shown them through his half-century of public life.\n\nBiden was greeted with raucous applause when he met with a group of labor leaders, an important part of his political base, on Wednesday, joining an AFL-CIO executive council meeting in Washington to discuss \"their shared commitment to defeating Donald Trump,\" the Biden campaign said.\n\nBiden listed high rents, expensive grocery prices and a lack of housing as issues to be tackled going forward.\n\nThere is \"a whole range of things we're going to get done with your help in a second term,\" Biden said. \"We're better positioned than any country in the world to own the remainder of the 21st century because of union labor.\"\n\nLabor votes were key to Biden's win over Trump in competitive states, including Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, in 2020.\n\n(Reporting by Trevor Hunnicutt and Jeff Mason; additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Jarrett Renshaw; Editing by Heather Timmons and Howard Goller)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"},
