{"uri": "2024-07-417831441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "19:05:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T19:05:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T19:05:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.heritage.org/progressivism/commentary/biden-has-always-been-liar", "title": "Biden Has Always Been a Liar", "body": "Joe Biden may be mentally incapacitated, but he's a truth-teller, unlike Trump, they claim.\n\nFramed on a wall in my office is a copy of my first opinion column, published by the Dallas Morning News on Oct. 11, 1987. Until then, I had been a wire service reporter and editor in Washington, D.C., and, before that, a sportswriter in Boston, but had never written opinion.\n\nWhen given the chance by the Morning News, I jumped on a subject that had piqued my curiosity: A senator for Delaware running for president had brazenly stolen a speech by a Welsh Labour Party leader in the United Kingdom and, when caught, paid the price by humiliatingly dropping out of the 1988 presidential race.\n\nThe Welsh politician was Neil Kinnock, and 27-year-old me simply used the brouhaha over the purloined speech as an excuse to praise him for daring to tell Labourites that \"socialism had become old hat,\" as I put it. Democrats should be stealing that speech, I wrote.\n\nThe senator for Delaware was President Joe Biden. Over the last 37 years since my column was published, I have watched him lie and lie again, sometimes about small things, other times about larger ones, but always with impunity.\n\n>>> The Left's $7 Trillion Lie: Biden Far Outpaces Trump in Racking Up the National Debt\n\nThe media are just as much to blame for Biden's habitual dishonesty because instead of covering him, they've covered for him.\n\nEven on those rare occasions when the legacy media have acknowledged that Biden is a fabulist, they have made excuses for him. The New York Times, for example, wrote protectively of him in 2022, saying that \"President Biden has been unable to break himself of the habit of embellishing narratives to weave a political identity.\"\n\nIt's not that he's lying, you see. Biden merely adorns reality.\n\nSometimes Biden's fabrications were just so oddball that they made you wonder if he was all there -- even before he started showing signs of senility. An example of this is Biden's insistence that his \"Uncle Bosie\" was eaten by cannibals in Papua New Guinea during World War II. The Defense Department was forced to put out a statement that Ambrose J. Finnegan was lost when his plane crashed in the Pacific Ocean.\n\nBiden has also lied about graduating in the top half of his law school class, having his house \"burn down with my wife in it,\" growing up in the Puerto Rican community, and once being the driver of \"an 18-wheeler\" to name only a handful of falsehoods that reveal a bizarre distance from reality.\n\nHe also habitually lies about former President Donald Trump leaving behind a 9% inflation rate. Inflation was 1.4% in January 2021.\n\nOther times, however, Biden's mendacity reveals a level of pathos that makes you want to look away. A case in point is when he told the mothers of the 13 soldiers killed in Afghanistan because of his ill-conceived pullout in 2021 that he could feel their pain because his son, Beau Biden, had also died in the war.\n\nIt was not the first time. Joe Biden has a history of saying that Beau Biden \"lost his life in Iraq.\" Beau Biden died tragically at the age of 46 in 2015 of cancer at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Maryland.\n\n\"We lost our son as well and brought him home in a flag-draped coffin,\" Cheryl Rex said the president told her. Rex later complained at a forum, \"My heart started beating faster, and I started shaking, knowing that their son died from cancer and they were able to be by his side.\"\n\nThe context was Joe Biden's stubborn insistence at the time that he was not culpable for the disastrous Afghanistan withdrawal. He was callously using his family's tragedy to buy sympathy. As the Wall Street Journal's Bill McGurn put it, \"Mr. Biden is not a gold star father and should stop playing one on TV.\"\n\n>>> Biden Lied, Your Wallet Died\n\nThis long record of deceitfulness was on display in the president's televised trainwreck of a debate with Trump on June 27, when he again lied about many things, including not having any military deaths during his term in office.\n\n\"I'm the only president this century that doesn't have any, this decade, that doesn't have any troops dying anywhere in the world,\" Joe Biden said at one point, ignoring the 13 body bags from the attack during his Afghanistan withdrawal, again painfully reminding the loved ones of those who died.\n\nJoe Biden also claimed that Trump left him a 15% unemployment rate, that he had been endorsed by the U.S. Border Patrol, and that Trump had told people to inject themselves with bleach during the pandemic. All these things were lies.\n\nIncongruously, post-debate Joe Biden is making truth-telling his badge against his display of precipitous cognitive degeneration. No, he doesn't debate as well as he used to, he angrily spat out at a rally on Friday, but \"I know what I do know -- I know how to tell the truth!\"\n\nAnd the media are there for him, regurgitating the new White House talking points. Joe Biden may be mentally incapacitated, but he's a truth-teller, unlike Trump, they claim.\n\n\"The ex-president got away with a torrent of lies,\" wrote a CNN senior reporter. You're all in, thank you,\" the First Lady said. \"And with four more years, Joe will continue to fight for you, the military community that he, that we are humbled and proud to call our own.\"\n\nThe First Lady reflected on the 2016 election and said people can't take anything for granted and need to face this moment as if freedoms are at risk.\n\n\"Remember that feeling about how you woke up, and you said to yourself, oh my god, what just happened?\" said Dr. Biden. \"We can't let that happen again.\"\n\nA handful of times, people in the crowd started cheering \"four more years.\"\n\nTampa Mayor Jane Castor also joined the First Lady on the stage Monday afternoon.\n\n\"When we all go to the polls this November, our choice will not only impact the lives of our veterans. Just not even selected clips, this is Joe Biden on the daily. Flubbing, mumbling, stumbling, bumbling, fumbling. I want to feel sorry, but I feel a little angry. I'm a little miffed for so many people in the media, in the Biden White House, on Jill Biden's staff, former colleagues of yours concealing this. They're not upset that Joe Biden is losing it. They're upset that we all know now and we all saw that he's losing it.\n\nLaRosa: So a couple of things, for context. So I haven't been there in about two years. But what I would say is it just wasn't my experience. I've been pretty consistent and I've been critical when I thought it warranted being critical. He did not... I'll just say this: the debate was as jarring and shocking to me as it was for a lot of people. It wasn't my experience when I was there. A lot of the gaffes that we were watching just now, I mean, that's been Joe Biden his entire career. He's always made flubs and gaffes and things like that. So to me, some of the speech vernacular was nothing new and nothing worrisome. There wasn't a doubt in my mind that that Joe Biden was up for the job, that he was cognitively aware and fully in command and control.\n\nShe also asked LaRosa if he thought Biden was going to stand by his insistence to remain in the race:\n\nConway: You're telling the audience right now that you think Jill and Joe Biden are going to dig in. {"uri": "8218712574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "12:40:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T12:40:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:40:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://dailycaller.com/2024/07/10/jill-biden-michael-larosa-jesse-watters/", "title": "'She Hates Politics': Jill Biden's Ex-Press Sec Answers For First Lady's Influence Over President Biden", "body": "First Lady Jill Biden's former press secretary Michael Larosa answered for the first lady's influence over her husband Tuesday evening on \"Jesse Watters Primetime.\"\n\nJill Biden, who reportedly makes the Marine Corps Band play her own \"Hail to the Chief\" style entrance theme, reportedly has the most influence over Biden regarding his reelection bid. Fox News host Jesse Watters pressed Larosa on Jill Biden's role in keeping President Joe Biden on the Democratic ticket.\n\n\"Tell me a little bit about Dr. Jill. We don't know her the way you know Dr. Jill. She apparently is telling Joe, 'Stay in,' and isn't listening to the press or anyone at all. Why?\" Watters asked.\n\nBiden quit his 1988 presidential campaign after reports surfaced in Sept. 1987 that he plagiarized a speech by British Opposition and Labour Party Leader Neil Kinnock. Larosa told Watters that the plagiarism scandal was \"scarring\" and a \"huge learning lesson\" for both Bidens.\n\n\"So, one thing that was so interesting about the George Stephanopoulos interview when he said that if, if we lose, he would have given it his all. And you've got a lot of flak for that, right? It reminded me so much what happened in 87' because as soon as he dropped out that same day, he was going into a hearing to chair the board hearings. And this really was gonna be, like, the next step for political rehab for him. Well, Jill was with him in the anti-room and she heard him say something very similar like, 'Well, at least I can go focus on this hearing now' and she cut him off and took him by the shoulders and just kind of hold by the lapels and said, 'No, you have to go f-ing win. And, uh, because she knew that was sort of the retaliation moment for him,\" Larosa said.\n\n\"And, you know, they were driven from that campaign, and I think they learned a long time ago they were gonna let line quotes or polls or pundits really push them out ever again,\" he continued. \"And I think that, that moment was scarring for them, Jesse. You know, she had never had his character or his integrity attacked before. He had been groomed to run for president for 15 years. He was our next, he was a great rising hope, and the way that campaign ended was pretty devastating for them. But it was a huge learning lesson in sort of political combat. You know, she's from Philly like you, so she likes to fight.\"\n\n\"Yeah, we love to fight. We like to scrap. And we'll just do it for fun. We don't care,\" Watters said. \"Did you hear Michael Moore at the top accuse Dr. Jill Biden of elder abuse? They just never did that with their, both of their aspirations. It just wasn't, it's not a 'Leave It to Beaver' 1950s ro -- you know, comedy for that. They're pretty independent. They left, they lived independent professional lives outside of each other's shadows.\"\n\n\"So, she would never... she would probably not -- this is his decision, you know? Biden has a packed schedule for the final three days of the week, and his public appearances are under more scrutiny now as Democrats have begun calling for him to drop out of the presidential race.\n\n\"With your help and your leadership, we're going to build this country from the bottom up and then middle out, not the top down,\" Biden told the union leaders. \"Now, they're warning me not to take too much time with you all today, in terms of talking.\"\n\nBiden wrapped up his remarks soon after the statement. He is scheduled to appear at the NATO summit in Washington, D.C., later on Wednesday.\n\nDEMOCRATS ARE IN A 'BIG-TIME PICKLE': LEE ZELDIN\n\nExperts say this multi-day summit is a \"pivotal\" moment for Biden, during which he must make his case that he is fit to serve as his party's nominee.\n\nFORMER WH PHYSICIAN PUSHES BACK ON KJP'S 'RIDICULOUS EXCUSE' SURROUNDING BIDEN'S DOCTOR VISITS\n\n\"This week is pivotal for President Biden, not only because of the intense interest in what he will be saying at his press events but also because this summit provides a clear example of restored American global leadership in support of our nation's defense,\" Joel Rubin, a former State Department official during the Obama administration, told Fox News Digital.\n\n\"The long-term bipartisan investment in NATO is paying off, and the president will have a chance, at this summit, to remind the American people about why his approach of building security coalitions with global partners advances both America's security abroad and our economy right here at home,\" he added.\n\nHOUSE DEMOCRATS REACH 'NO CONSENSUS' ON BIDEN AFTER 'TOP SECRET' CLOSED-DOOR MEETING\n\nBiden has faced growing resistance to his campaign for re-election ever since his debate against the presumptive GOP nominee, former President Trump, which many deemed a disaster for showcasing the president in a worse light than many anticipated. {"uri": "2024-07-417694123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "16:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T16:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T12:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4000000059604645, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/opinion/articles/2024-07-10/ive-worked-with-first-ladies-dont-underestimate-jill-bidens-influence-on-the-president", "title": "I've Worked With First Ladies. Don't Underestimate Jill Biden's Influence on the President", "body": "President Joe Biden's widely criticized debate performance started a vocal fight within the Democratic Party, with some leaders publicly calling on him to leave the race while others continue to support his candidacy. Biden, meanwhile, has shrunk his circle of influence and declared that only the \"Lord Almighty\" could persuade him to step down.\n\nWith just a month to go before the Democratic National Convention, replacing the top of the ticket would mean moving mountains from a procedural perspective. And who would take his place? According to a recent Reuters/Ipsos poll of Democratic voters, former first lady Michelle Obama is the leading - and only - candidate who could beat Donald Trump, though she has said again and again that she is not interested in running. The former first lady also topped a list of Democrats favored by young adults surveyed in a new U.S. News-Generation Lab poll released July 10.\n\nBut history shows that in fact it's the current first lady who almost certainly has the best chance of shaping this race. It's Jill Biden - not former Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, not Democratic congressional leaders Hakeem Jeffries or Chuck Schumer, not longtime advisers Ron Klain and Anita Dunn - whom the president listens to when weighing his political future. That should not come as a surprise.\n\nAs my co-authors and I wrote in our book, \"Remember the First Ladies,\" American presidents' wives throughout history have been their most valued political confidantes, using their unique, unfireable position and unlimited access to the president to shape their spouses' personal and political decisions. Much of this influence has been misunderstood or under-reported by the media and in history books.\n\nConsider Eleanor Roosevelt, who persuaded Franklin Delano Roosevelt to stay in politics after he was afflicted with polio. She gave speeches and campaigned in his place, helping to insulate him from voters seeing the realities of his disability. In a close parallel to today, Nancy Reagan grabbed hold of the debate process and accused Ronald Reagan's advisers of over-briefing him after his poor performance in the first debate of the 1984 re-election. In his second term, she exercised control over her husband's schedule and squelched talk that he was showing signs of dementia.\n\nThe most striking example of a first lady's influence, though, is Edith Wilson, whose husband Woodrow suffered a severe stroke late in his second term. Rather than advising him to resign, she kept him going by taking charge of matters of state - an extraordinary overreach, functionally running the executive branch for the remainder of Wilson's second term.\n\nIt is worth noting, however, a different example of a first lady deploying her influence: Lady Bird Johnson advised Lyndon as early as his 1964 campaign not to run for re-election in 1968. History has not damned Johnson for following her advice; even his critics praised his March 1968 speech declaring he would not run again, because it was clear how much he cared about the nation.\n\nJill Biden wrote in her 2019 memoir, \"Where the Light Enters,\" that she, too, had urged her husband not to run in 2004, when his advisers were telling him he should. She recounted walking into the political strategy huddle in a bikini with the word \"NO\" written on her stomach. He listened to her then, and there is little doubt that he is listening to her now; this time, she seems to have his advisers onside, working overtime to shore up congressional support.\n\nJill Biden now faces a dilemma: whether to use her considerable sway with the president to encourage him to stay in the race, or to follow in the footsteps of Lady Bird Johnson and recommend a graceful exit.\n\nThe Bidens' public career is long. They have been through a lot together. Over the past four decades, Jill Biden grew from a family-centered educator and reluctant political spouse to the president's most popular campaign surrogate. She reportedly urged her husband to run again at the beginning of this cycle, and she is apparently advocating for him to stay in the race because of a genuine belief he is the only person who can beat former president Trump.\n\nPolitics is a family affair, and the counsel of Jill Biden, like first ladies before her, cannot be ignored. As first lady Florence Harding famously said, \"I know what's best for the President. I put him in the White House.\"\n\nWhile the world listens to what members of Congress, Democratic Party elites and members of the media are saying about what the president should do, I encourage you to pay most attention to the first lady. It is she who is uniquely positioned to determine the fate of this race.\n\nAnita McBride is director of the First Ladies Initiative at American University, former chief of staff to first lady Laura Bush and one of the longest-serving women in White House history, serving three administrations across the East and West Wings. She is co-author of \"Remember the First Ladies: The Legacies of America's History-Making Women\" and co-founder of the First Ladies Association for Research and Education.", "source": {"uri": We will continue to fight'.\n\nAnd her determination to keep the drum beating for the 81-year-old candidate has been seized upon by conservatives who are painting her as a Lady Macbeth character.\n\nMegyn Kelly, a former Fox News anchor, called her a \"power-hungry aspirant\" running a \"shadow presidency\", while the Drudge Report declared: \"Cruel Jill clings to power\". Harriet Hageman, a Republican congresswoman for Wyoming, said Jill was guilty of \"elder abuse\" for \"rolling President Biden out on stage to engage in a battle of wits while unarmed\".\n\nEven her first husband, Bill Stevenson, to whom she was married from 1970 to 1975, chimed in, saying: \"I just don't understand why she is so adamant about defending him and keeping him in the race since it appears that he's struggling.\"\n\nIn a TV interview on Monday, Trump speculated: \"I think Jill would like to see him stay, she's having a good time.\"\n\nHowever, in a speech in Wilmington, North Carolina, Jill, 73, painted herself as a supportive wife rather than an ambitious political spouse or someone who had grown accustomed to the trappings of the White House.\n\n\"For all the talk out there about this race, Joe has made it clear that he's all in,\" Jill, who also visited Georgia and Florida, said. \"That's the decision he's made -- and just as he has always supported my career, I am all in too.\"\n\nThose who know her also insist that she has no personal desire for power. Elizabeth Alexander, her communications director, said she sees her role as \"an act of service\" to the nation.\n\nBut many are asking why, as her husband's closest confidante and most trusted sounding board, she does not urge him to drop out, for the sake of his health and his legacy. She has not been shy about confronting Biden's political ambitions in the past.\n\n* Joe Biden's health: how mentally fit is the president?\n\nIn the early years of their relationship -- during which she refused three marriage proposals -- she was famously unenthusiastic about her husband's political aspirations, and she vetoed a presidential run for the 2004 election.\n\nThis time she insists it is different because of what is at stake. \"As commander-in-chief, President Biden wakes up every morning ready to work for you,\" she told a crowd of military veterans and their families in North Carolina, noting how Trump is said to have called those who died in the line of duty \"suckers\" and \"losers\". Trump denies the claim.\n\nShe added: \"Donald Trump wakes up every morning thinking of one person and one person only: himself.\"\n\nIt was a \"business as usual\" approach, but the strain was evident. Normally a relaxed and sunny figure, who takes pride in her calm demeanour, she snapped -- albeit with a smile -- at the journalists demanding her take on her husband's battle for survival.\n\n\"Why are you screaming at me?\" she said, pausing on the tarmac before boarding her plane. \"You know me. Don't scream at me. {"uri": "8219477464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-10", "time": "22:57:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-10T22:57:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-10T22:53:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2782620/", "title": "Joe Biden and Donald Trump make their respective candidacies possible - ExBulletin", "body": "Deeply unpopular with much of the American public and clearly unsuited to the presidency to which they hope to be reelected, Donald Trump and Joe Biden both seem ripe for replacement by younger, more competent, and less repulsive candidates. But while Biden in particular could be pushed aside to make way for someone else, they currently exist in a state of political symbiosis. Biden and Trump may hate each other, but each owes much of his political viability to the failures of his opponent.\n\nThe Rattler is a weekly newsletter from JD Tuccille. If you care about government overreach and tangible threats to everyday freedom, this newsletter is for you.\n\nNobody likes them\n\nIn April, an AP-NORC poll found that \"the public generally believes that the presidencies of Joe Biden and Donald Trump have done more harm than good, but each president is viewed negatively on different issues.\" Specifically, about half of respondents said Biden had harmed the United States on the cost of living, immigration, and foreign relations. A similar share said Trump had harmed voting rights, election security, foreign relations, abortion, and climate change.\n\nUnsurprisingly, that same month, Pew Research reported that \"voters have little overall confidence in either candidate on a number of key dimensions, including fitness for office, personal ethics, and respect for democratic values.\" Forty-nine percent of them said they favored replacing Biden and Trump as the major-party presidential nominees.\n\nAs of Tuesday, Trump had an approval rating of 38.6 percent, according to ABC News/FiveThirtyEight (57.9 percent disapproval). That's low, but it's higher than Biden's 37.4 percent (56.8 percent disapproval). These are two political candidates who appear to threaten to be dead weight for their respective political parties, hurting their chances of winning at the polls. But in truth, each has a secret weapon: their much-hated opponent.\n\n\"Biden can probably only win if he runs against a candidate as unpopular as Trump,\" CNN senior reporter Harry Enten said last September. \"Trump can probably only win if he runs against a candidate as unpopular as Biden.\"\n\nParties could do better\n\nPolls confirm the weakness of both men. While Biden is falling further and further behind Trump after a disastrous debate performance that highlighted his cognitive decline, voters narrowly prefer Vice President Kamala Harris over the former president, 42% to 41%, and former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, 43% to 41%, according to a recent Bendixen & Amandi poll.\n\nAlong the same lines, a CBS News/YouGov poll from January showed Trump beating Biden 50% to 48%. But Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis edged Biden 51% to 48%, and former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley edged the incumbent 53% to 45%.\n\nVoters from all major parties chose relatively weak candidates, bolstered by equally questionable decisions from their counterparts across the political spectrum.\n\nDisturb the balance\n\nOf course, things have changed in recent weeks, after the presidential debate that was supposed to showcase Joe Biden's dynamism had exactly the opposite effect. The incumbent's jumble of incoherent words and lackluster demeanor have not only raised questions about his ability to campaign for four more years in the White House, but also serious concerns that whoever was making the presidential decisions was not the person behind the podium that night.\n\n\"Even some in the West Wing policy process don't know exactly what policy issues are getting to the president and how,\" Semafor's Ben Smith said, according to an unnamed government official. \"The big decisions are made in an opaque circle that includes White House chief of staff Jeff Zients (who speaks to the president regularly) and the back end is done.\"\n\nThe fallout from that disastrous debate and the sobering interviews that followed have upended the symbiotic political relationship that had balanced Biden's obvious failures with Trump's glaring flaws. National and battleground polls show Donald Trump increasingly ahead of Joe Biden, with averages putting the Republican's national advantage at anywhere from 2% to more than 3%. That has leading Democrats battling over whether Biden should be replaced as the party's standard-bearer heading into the election.\n\nA new candidate without Biden's cognitive deficits and political baggage could well erase Trump's advantage. Voters who have resigned themselves to voting for the Republican candidate simply because he is not Biden might decide differently if Democrats offered another option. That is, they might do so if it were a less bad option.\n\nFor now, the most likely replacement is Vice President Kamala Harris, who would inherit the Biden-Harris campaign apparatus and, more importantly, the money. But despite a slight edge in the Bendixen & Amandi poll, she is not widely liked (37.1% approve, 51.2% disapprove). Harris has a reputation as an authoritarian former prosecutor who mistreated her staff until they resigned en masse, and as an intellectual lightweight who is simply not up to the limited demands of the vice presidency, let alone the White House.\n\nThe candidates who remain in the running?\n\nReplacing Biden with Harris might simply be trading a disabled candidate for one who would have no obvious advantage heading into the race, other than a greater likelihood of living to see Election Day.\n\nFor his part, Biden (or someone acting on his behalf) insists that he is \"firmly committed to staying in the race, to seeing this race through to the end\" and that he \"would not run again if I were not absolutely convinced that I am the best person to beat Donald Trump in 2024.\"\n\nUnless Biden or his entourage changes their minds, it appears he will have a chance to try. With his leadership position in the Republican Party and his lead in the polls, Trump is the GOP's surefire nominee. Regardless of what so many Americans want, the two mutually dependent rivals seem destined to once again present voters with a choice between struggling and unpopular candidates.\n\nOf course, the real problem here is not just the candidates, but the parties and a political system that offer such flawed options to a nation of 330 million people. If the best candidates they can find are viable candidates only because they balance their respective horrors, then a better way to screen potential candidates needs to be found, as well as broader access to the ballot for potential candidates.\n\nTo this day, we are stuck with options that few people want. May the least terrible choice, if there is one, prevail.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": We observed more churn between those who favored either Biden or Trump and the \"Other\" category.\n\nAbout 4% of Biden's and 6% of Trump's supporters in the earlier wave shifted to \"Other\" post-debate. At the same time, 6% of \"Other\" shifted to Biden, and another 6% shifted to Trump.\"\n\nTherefore, there really isn't any statistical support for the claim that voters have abandoned Joe Biden or that there's some urgent need for Democrats to replace their nominee.\n\nThere are a bunch of very rich white men in positions of privilege still calling for Joe Biden to drop out, and they need to zip it all up.\n\nRob Reiner, Stephens Colbert and King, George Clooney, and other rich white dudes who won't be impacted by Project 2025 at all are calling for Joe Biden--again, the most successful President since the 1960's--to step down and be replaced by *checks notes* nobody with a track record like his.\n\nMeanwhile, Trump not only had yet another unhinged meltdown last night in Florida, he's having another one at Mar-A-Lago as I write this.
